There are many previous examples of Lords members holding Cabinet positions. Baroness Morgan served as secretary of state for digital, culture, media and sport under Boris Johnson from July 2019 until February 2020.
Lord Peter Mandelson was business secretary and, effectively, deputy prime minister in Gordon Brown's government, despite having left the Commons in 2004.
Lord Andrew Adonis also served as transport secretary in the same government, despite never having been elected to the Commons.
Lord Cameron will sit in the Lords, rather than the Commons, which will add some complications to his Cabinet role.
It will mean a significant portion of his everyday business will be delegated to his second in command – currently Andrew Mitchell, the international development minister.
Lord Cameron was prime minister between 2010 and 2016 but quit after losing the Brexit referendum to Vote Leave.
In his resignation speech Lord Cameron said he was 'very proud and very honoured to have been prime minister of this country for six years'.
He continued: 'Although leaving Europe was not the path I recommended, I am the first to praise our incredible strengths.
'I said before that Britain can survive outside the European Union and indeed that we could find a way.
'Now the decision has been made to leave, we need to find the best way and I will do everything I can to help.'
Initially Lord Cameron said he would remain on the Conservative backbenches, but on 12 September, 2016 he announced he would be resigning his Witney, Oxfordshire seat with immediate effect.
Lord Cameron held the seat for 15 years, first entering the Commons in June 2001. He was succeeded by Robert Courts, who remains in the role.
Upon resigning, the former prime minister said he didn't want his presence on the backbenches to serve as a 'distraction' to Theresa May, who replaced him in No 10.
'As a former PM it's very difficult to sit as a backbencher and not be an enormous diversion and distraction from what the government is doing,' he said. 'I don't want to be that distraction.'

title: What will Suella Braverman do next? Leadership race, TV shows and ECHR campaign options
lead: Suella Braverman could be a headache for Rishi Sunak on the backbenches
author: Eleanor Langford

body.text: Following her widely expected sacking in Monday's reshuffle, Suella Braverman released a brief statement claiming that serving as home secretary was 'the greatest privilege' of her life and, in a rather ominous warning, that she would have 'more to say' about her exit in due course.

It was her outspoken views that led to her downfall, with Mr Sunak firing her over her controversial comments around pro-Palestine marches and rough sleepers, as well as for breaching collective responsibility among Cabinet ministers.
The question now is what Ms Braverman will do next as a backbench MP and what more she has to say about her dramatic departure from the Home Office.
As Ms Braverman moves from the frontbench of the Commons to the back, she will likely be considering what kind of role she wants to play as a former secretary of state.

Her predecessor, Priti Patel, has taken a very measured approach to life after Government, throwing herself into campaigning for her Witham seat and launching the occasional scathing attack on the current administration.
Others, like Theresa May, who is a former prime minister as well as an ex-home secretary, have assumed the role of elder statesman, making well-time interventions that always capture attention.

Liz Truss, another notable figure in the party, has been able to fill rooms at party conferences but rarely makes speeches in Parliament, preferring instead to make policy speeches elsewhere on specific issues.

Ms Braverman's differences with Mr Sunak on policy were a large part of her downfall, and her next step will likely be considering how, free of the collective responsibility requirements of Cabinet, she can best make her views heard in the Commons from the backbenches.
On the evening of the reshuffle, members of Tory caucuses, the New Conservatives and the Common Sense Group, met to discuss the day's event and what it meant for them.
There is a growing disquiet among the Tory right that Mr Sunak's lurch to the centre could mean a softening of the Government's stance on immigration, a key issue for many MPs from the 2019 intake.

Much of Ms Braverman's remaining support in the group is concentrated among these MPs and, if she decides to make trouble for Mr Sunak, she could rally them behind her on key issues like the future of the Rwanda policy.

MPs have warned that, if the Government does soften or scrap the Rwanda deportation plan, the Prime Minister could be seeing letters of no confidence in the New Year, a movement Ms Braverman may quietly want to be a part of.
Ms Braverman has never kept secret her desire for the UK to leave the European Convention on Human Rights (ECHR), a move backed by many Tory MPs on the right of the party.

The international treaty – which protects the right to life, freedom from torture, freedom from slavery, freedom of expression, and other rights – has been a key part of court challenges to the Government's Rwanda plan.

So strong is her conviction, that reports prior to her sacking suggested the former home secretary was pushing for the party to run a 'Quit the ECHR' election campaign similar to Boris Johnson's 2019 'Get Brexit Done' campaign, according to the Mail on Sunday.
While her successor, James Cleverly, has previously publicly opposed scrapping the ECHR from UK law, her views on it are shared by Robert Jenrick, the immigration minister.
With many hard-right Tory MPs on her side, Ms Braverman may make pushing from the backbenches for the UK to drop the treaty a key mission of hers.
During the 2022 Conservative leadership race following the resignation of Boris Johnson, Ms Braverman positioned herself as the candidate of the Tory right.
The vote was split, however, by fellow right-leaning candidate Kemi Badenoch and she ended up coming sixth in the race which was ultimately won by Liz Truss.
If the Conservatives lose the next general election, it's widely expected that another leadership election will follow, with both Ms Badenoch and Ms Braverman likely to run.

Tory MPs have suggested to Informfully that she still harbours ambitions to run again if a contest comes up, but she will have to persuade both members of her own party and the grassroots Tory membership to back her.
The ConservativeHome rankings of Cabinet ministers, published before her sacking, showed that she had a net satisfaction rating of 43.5, way above Rishi Sunak who is on 7.1.

She is beaten in the rankings, however, by previous Conservative leadership contenders Penny Mordaunt and Ms Badenoch, with her successor Mr Cleverly, who ran for the leadership in 2019, coming out on top.
While Ms Braverman may hope to run for leader one day in the future, she could struggle to garner the support she needs within her party to become Mr Sunak's successor.

Many former secretaries of state have gone on to become prolific media figures including Boris Johnson, Nadine Dorries and Jacob Rees-Mogg. Current deputy party chairman, Lee Anderson, who is a key supporter of Ms Braverman also has his own show on GB News.
With this precedent set, Ms Braverman may be tempted to make more appearances on TV and in newspapers to get her views across.
She already has a reputation for being outspoken, and it was her controversial language on pro-Palestine marches and rough sleepers that ultimately led to Mr Sunak choosing to sack her.

Anything she earns from these ventures will have to be declared, and pursing a media career isn't without its own controversy. Many have argued against MPs, who are elected to represent their constituents and scrutinise legislation, having second jobs.

title: ‘We’re so bad we had to turn to Cameron’: Tory grassroots’ verdict on Sunak’s reshuffle
lead: Loyal Conservative activists also backed Rishi Sunak’s decision to sack Suella Braverman as Home Secretary
author: David Parsley

body.text: Tory grassroot activists have broadly welcomed the return of David Cameron to frontline politics and the party's shift to the centre right, but still believe the Conservatives face a 'tough challenge' at the next general election.

Local Conservative figures also welcomed Rishi Sunak's sacking of Suella Braverman, claiming that her 'inappropriate language' on homelessness and protests did not represent the views of the majority of Tory supporters despite claims to the contrary from the former home secretary.

The return of the former prime minister, who was made a Lord in order to allow him to become Foreign Secretary, was the shock move in Mr Sunak's wide-ranging cabinet reshuffle, which also included the appointment of Victoria Atkins as health secretary and the sacking of Thérèse Coffey as environment secretary.
Abi Brown, a Tory activist in Stoke-on-Trent and former leader of the local group, said: 'I'm pleased to see David Cameron coming back into the Government.
'For a Red Wall area like Stoke, the things that he has talked about are very much in line with our aspirations as a place.'
On Ms Braverman's sacking, Ms Brown said her position had become 'untenable'.
'I think she oversimplified things to suggest that everybody who lives in a place like Stoke-on-Trent agreed with her characterisation of the pro-Palestinian protests as hate marches.
'We didn't win three Conservative seats around here with views like that. We won them under the centre right polices of David Cameron and Theresa May.
'So, I believe the changes to the Cabinet will, maybe, get us back on track a little bit.'

Sean McDonald, co-chairman of Worthing West Conservatives, welcomed the return of Lord Cameron after seven years away from Parliament, but he was uncertain whether it would be enough to turn the Government's fortunes around at the next general election
'I think he's [Cameron] very good. So, he may be an asset. I'm not 100 per cent certain, but I think he will be an asset.

'I think it's going to be a tough election to win. I've been out canvassing this morning, and what I'm finding is that people don't want to vote for anybody at the moment. They don't believe either Tories or Labour are good enough.'

Leon Spence, chairman of the Tory association in North West Leicestershire, added: 'I think it's an excellent decision to bring David back. He brings gravitas and statesmanship into the Government. And I think that's always to be welcomed.'

Mr Spence said Ms Braverman had to go following her comments around the marches and her wish to fine charities for providing tents to the homeless, adding they were a 'breach of collective responsibility' of the Cabinet.

Other senior grassroot Tories agree that the party's shift to the centre ground could boost the Conservatives' chances at the general election, which is widely expected to take place at some point next year.

David Ashton, former chairman of Harrow East Conservative, said: 'I think it's a bold move and a little bit surprising, but David Cameron has a lot of experience and I think Rishi could find that helpful.'

Julian Ellacott, chairman of the Surrey Conservative Partnership and a member of the national party's board, said: 'I've always been a big fan of David Cameron. To have him back is probably a good thing.'
However, there was some disappointment in Lord Cameron's appointment from Tory loyalists.
Harvey Unwin, the former chairman of Telford Conservatives, believes the controversy around his lobbying of the Government on behalf of investment firm Greensill Capital could taint his return.
In 2021, documents suggested Lord Cameron made around £8.2m jetting around the world to promote the finance business.

Before Greensill collapsed in March 2021, the former Prime Minister had lobbied civil servants, as well as Mr Sunak to change the rules to allow Greensill to join the emergency Covid loan schemes, applying pressure by making phone calls and sending dozens of texts and emails.
Criminal inquiries into alleged fraud are ongoing in Germany and Switzerland, where Lex Greensill has been named as a suspect.
Mr Unwin said: 'I think it's a very odd appointment because he's been out of frontline politics for seven years.
'I must be honest, we've got the Greensill issue in the background, which could be quite difficult for him going forward.'
Another Tory activist suggested Lord Cameron's appointment also suggested that Mr Sunak 'does not think much' of the quality of backbench Tory MPs.

Matt Stephens, the former chairman of Hitchin and Harpenden Conservatives, added: 'What Rishi is saying to us is that among the 350 Tory MPs there's no one with the competence or capability to do that role.
'We're that bad that we've had to wind the clock back seven years.'

title: Who is Victoria Atkins? The new health secretary and the challenges she faces
lead: Prior to her political career, Ms Atkins was a criminal barrister specialising in prosecuting serious organised crime
author: Isobel Frodsham

body.text: Victoria Atkins has been promoted to Health Secretary in the Prime Minister's cabinet reshuffle.
The former Treasury minister replaced Steve Barclay in the surprise announcement yesterday, which was triggered by the sacking of former Home Secretary Suella Braverman.
Ms Atkins takes on the role during a challenging time for the NHS, with ongoing discussions over pay deals for doctors following several walkouts this year.
The politician is the MP for Louth and Horncastle in Lincolnshire, having represented the constituency since 2015.
The 47-year-old is from a political family – her father is Sir Robert Atkins, a former MEP and and former Tory MP for Preston North and latterly South Ribble, in Lancashire.
Her mother is Lady Dulcie Atkins, a Tory councillor for Wyre Council in Lancashire.
She has held numerous ministerial posts prior to her joining Mr Sunak's cabinet, serving in Theresa May and Boris Johnson's governments.

Her previous roles have included Parliamentary Undersecretary of State for Women, Parliamentary under-Secretary of State for Safeguarding, Afghan Resettlement Minister, Prisons and Probation Minister and latterly Treasury Minister.
Prior to her political career, she was a criminal barrister specialising in prosecuting serious organised crime.
Ms Atkins is married to Paul Kenward, who is the chief executive of one of the world's biggest sugar companies, ABF Sugar.
Victoria Atkins MP has been appointed Secretary of State for Health and Social Care @DHSCgovuk pic.twitter.com/T1K0a1lv7Q
Following a difficult three years globally as a result of the Covid-19 pandemic, Ms Atkins will be picking up where Mr Barclay left off during a tricky time for the UK's public health service.
Last Thursday, new NHS England figures showed that an estimated 6.5 million people were waiting to start treatment at the end of September, up from 6.47m in August.

In terms of actual appointments, which includes individuals who are waiting for more than one treatment, the waiting list has increased to a new high of 7.77 million people at the end of September, up from 7.75 million at the end of August.
Meanwhil affected e strikes have been ongoing in the NHS since December 2022 and are understood to havemore than one million appointments.
Last week it emerged that hospitals would be allowed to cut back on pre-planned care to help cover the cost of previous walk outs, which is thought to be around £1bn.
The Government is in talks with consultants and specialist, associate specialist and specialty (SAS) doctors, the British Medical Association (BMA) said earlier in November.
It confirmed both groups would be reballoted on industrial action and, if passed, it would give them a mandate to strike until June 2024.

Outlining her plans for her position, Ms Atkins said last night: 'Our NHS matters to us all, and I look forward to working with NHS and social care colleagues to bolster services during what promises to be a very challenging winter, cut waiting lists and improve patient care.
'I am also determined to drive forward discussions with striking unions in order to end the ongoing industrial action which has caused so much disruption to patients.'
Sir Julian Hartley, who is the chief executive of NHS Providers, which represents health trusts, said: 'This change comes at a critical juncture for the sector, which faces unprecedented challenges.
'Top of the agenda is the resolution to ongoing industrial action. The cumulative impact of strikes on patients, staff and the NHS cannot be understated.
'Constructive dialogue between the Government and unions is key to finding a sustainable solution.'
Chairman of the Health and Social Care Committee Steve Brine said: '[Ms Atkins's] appointment comes at a critical time for the NHS with the number of patients waiting for treatment at a record high.
'Preventing ill health will be key to helping the NHS manage its resources. Prevention is one of this committee's priorities and I hope it will be high up on the new Secretary of State's agenda too.'

title: Tory Brexiteers ‘depressed’ by return of ex-PM David Cameron who fronted Remain campaign
lead: Ex-PM’s appointment as foreign secretary risks reopening Tory splits on Brexit and China
author: Arj Singh

body.text: David Cameron's appointment as foreign secretary risks reopening Conservative splits over Brexit and China due to his past leading the Remain campaign and fostering close relations with Beijing.

Downing Street insisted Lord Cameron believes in Brexit and will help the Government's efforts to make it a success despite fronting the Remain campaign in the 2016 referendum and subsequently quitting as prime minister because he felt he could not be the man to take the UK out of the EU.

But while some Leavers welcomed Lord Cameron's appointment despite his past, one source on the Conservative arch-Brexiteer European Research Group (ERG) said they were 'too depressed to think about it'.
Brexiteer Tory donor Lord Cruddas of Shoreditch, an ally of Vote Leave leader Boris Johnson, meanwhile proclaimed of the reshuffle: 'The coup is complete, Remain has won and democracy has lost.

However, Tory MP for Dewsbury Mark Eastwood told Informfully he was 'really pleased' with the appointment, revealing that 'he inspired me to get actively involved with the party and run for elections, back in 2009'.
'Despite us campaigning on different sides during the EU referendum, I was genuinely disappointed when he resigned,' the MP added.
'(It's) great to have him back in frontline politics.'

Lord Cameron's appointment also risks deepening divisions over the UK's treatment of China, as the former premier previously heralded a 'golden era' in relations with Beijing and hosted President Xi Jinping on a state visit where the pair shared a pint of beer in a pub.

His appointment in 2017 as vice-chair of the £1bn China-UK investment fund was also questioned by Parliament's Intelligence and Security Committee as possibly 'in some part engineered by the Chinese state to lend credibility to Chinese investment, as well as to the broader China brand'.

Luke de Pulford, executive director of the Inter-Parliamentary Alliance on China, described it as an 'incomprehensible, retrograde appointment' because 'Cameron is out of step with Parliament and the country on China'.
'Look forward to (Lord Cameron) declaring exactly how much he has been paid to represent Beijing's interests since leaving No 10,' he added.
Alicia Kearns, Tory chair of the Foreign Affairs Committee, meanwhile told Bloomberg: 'David Cameron will find Parliament has changed a lot when it comes to China.
'Relations with China are our foremost challenge and he is going to have quite a challenge getting foreign policy into the place where it needs to be going forward.'
Lord Cameron's appointment was also criticised by Commons Speaker Sir Lindsay Hoyle because MPs will not be able to question him as he will sit in the House of Lords.

He said: 'This is not the first time in recent years that a Cabinet minister has been appointed in the House of Lords, but given the gravity of the current international situation, it is especially important that this House is able to scrutinise the work of the Foreign, Commonwealth and Development Office effectively.
'I have therefore commissioned advice from the clerks about possible options for enhancing (scrutiny) of the work of the foreign secretary when that post is filled by a member of the other House.
'I also look forward to hearing the Government's proposals on how the foreign secretary will be properly accountable to this House.'
Downing Street insisted Rishi Sunak was 'looking to the future' rather than dwelling on the past while defending Lord Cameron's appointment despite his opposition to Brexit.
The Prime Minister's press secretary said: 'We're at a point now where we are looking to the future, we're not looking to the past as a party.
'We have a PM that voted Brexit, believed in it, has championed it, so that's what we're focused on.'
Asked if Lord Cameron believes in Brexit, she said: 'Yes, of course. We are making Brexit a success.'

On China, the Prime Minister's official spokesman told reporters the Foreign Secretary would be 'taking forward' the Government's existing position on China – that it poses an 'epoch-defining and systemic challenge' to the UK.
Lord Cameron said he will be held accountable properly in his new role, despite not facing regular questioning from MPs in the Commons.
'I will be held to account in the House of Lords where I have to account for myself and the Government,' he said during his first interview as foreign secretary.
He said Foreign Office minister Andrew Mitchell and others will be held to account in the lower chamber.

Lord Cameron said: 'Of course, this Government, my role in it, all of that will be accountable to the electorate at the general election when it comes but in the meantime I want to do everything to strengthen our alliances, to work with our friends, to build those vital partnerships, to make sure our country is secure and prosperous in a difficult and dangerous world.'

title: Rishi Sunak’s Cameron gamble: PM goes back to the future to try and boost Tories
lead: Just last month, Rishi Sunak sold himself as the change candidate and the antidote to decades of political consensus, in an apparent rebuke of David Cameron’s premiership
author: Arj Singh

body.text: Rishi Sunak handed David Cameron a shock return to frontline politics on Monday in a dramatic reshuffle that shifted the Cabinet towards the centre ground in a bid to stave off election defeat.
But the Prime Minister risked a major backlash from right-wing Conservatives after sacking Suella Braverman as home secretary following days of speculation over her political future.

Lord Cameron, who has been rushed into the House of Lords, was appointed Foreign Secretary to replace fellow Tory moderate James Cleverly, in what marked the first return of a former prime minister to government since Alec Douglas-Home in the 1970s.
Mr Cleverly in turn replaced Ms Braverman as Home Secretary in a pair of moves that appeared to change the political direction of the Government.
Just a month ago, Mr Sunak had declared himself the change candidate and the antidote to decades of political consensus, in an apparent rebuke of Mr Cameron's premiership between 2010 and 2016.
It came as the Prime Minister announced his decision to scrap northern leg of HS2, a move publicly criticised by Mr Cameron.

But with the Conservatives trailing Labour by nearly 20 points in the polls, Mr Sunak carried out a dramatic reset of his top team, days after Ms Braverman had caused outrage by criticising the police over its handling of pro-Palestinian protests.
Ministers from the centre-right of the party hailed the move, with one telling Informfully Mr Sunak had brought in 'sensible voices'. Another described Lord Cameron's appointment as 'inspired'.
One Tory insider declared simply: 'Christmas came early for liberal Conservatives.'

But other ministers privately expressed concerns that Mr Sunak had failed to ensure right-wing representation at a senior enough level, despite Esther McVey being handed a Cabinet return as an anti-woke 'common sense minister'.
The backlash began almost immediately, as former minister Dame Andrea Jenkyns submitted a letter of no confidence in Mr Sunak as a result of his decision to axe Ms Braverman.

The new Foreign Secretary sought to gloss over past disagreements with Mr Sunak on EU membership and HS2, telling broadcasters: 'Though I may have disagreed with some individual decisions, it is clear to me that Rishi Sunak is a strong and capable Prime Minister, who is showing exemplary leadership at a difficult time.'
Lord Cameron also attempted to brush off questions on the Greensill affair, in which he privately lobbied ministers in an attempt to win Greensill Capital access to an emergency Covid loan scheme.
'As far as I am concerned, that is all dealt with and in the past,' he said.
Mr Sunak's press secretary said the reshuffle reflected his focus on having a 'strongly united team'.
Questioned on whether the Prime Minister was alienating right-wingers, she said: 'We govern for the country, we don't govern for one particular way of thinking'.

title: Rishi Sunak’s bold Cameron gambit won’t save the Tories at general election, pollsters say
lead: Snap poll showed voters divided over bringing back the former prime minister
author: Richard Vaughan

body.text: The appointment of Lord David Cameron and a raft of moderate Tory MPs to the Cabinet is an attempt by Rishi Sunak to secure his base in the South but is unlikely to save the party at the general election, pollsters have said.

The Prime Minister stunned Westminster by recalling his predecessor to frontline politics as Foreign Secretary after he sacked Suella Braverman as home secretary following her repeated outbursts over pro-Palestine marches and homelessness.

According to polling experts, Mr Sunak's decision to fire Ms Braverman and take his party back to the centre ground comes as part of an attempt to stage a major reset by stabilising his core vote in the so-called 'Blue Wall' in the South and South East.

It came as snap YouGov polling showed the jury was still out on the decision to bring Lord Cameron back from the political wilderness, with 38 per cent stating it was a bad move, as opposed to 24 per cent believing it to be a good decision.

The public's views were far less equivocal when it came to the decision to remove Ms Braverman, with 57 per cent stating the Prime Minister was right to sack her, while just 20 per cent said he was wrong to do so.

Patrick English, director of political analytics at YouGov, said when the polling results on Lord Cameron's appointment was broken down by region it showed the move was motivated by appealing to the Blue Wall.
The figures show a far more nuanced picture, particularly in London, where 31 per cent said it was a good appointment as opposed to 32 per cent who said it was a bad decision.

Mr English told i: 'What we are seeing is a Prime Minister, who is looking at the current lie of the land, and the policy of being tough on this, and tough on that, and decided it is not working and it is time for a reset.

'He has obviously thought that by going back to Cameroonism, including Cameron himself, he can appeal to those areas where he is still looked upon favourably and with those places back in the bag, he can try and build up in other areas, such as the Midlands, the North and those ‘Red Wall‘ seats.'

The decision has further divided Tory MPs, with those on the right of the party furious with the appointment, while those on the more moderate wing insist that he is a necessary safe pair of hands and a break from the hardline approach taken to date by Mr Sunak.
Luke Tryl, director of More in Common, said the appointment of centrists, such as Lord Cameron, chimes more closely with how the public views the Prime Minister.

'When he first came in, people may have seen Rishi Sunak as out of touch but they certainly didn't see him as the change candidate. There was a realisation that he was in danger of falling between two stools and that he could lose among both Red Wall voters and more liberal Tory voters,' Mr Tryl said.

But he added: 'For most people this reshuffle will not change things. It is still really hard to see Rishi Sunak as Prime Minister after the next election, but there is still time for the Tories to avoid a 1997 type result.
'Much will depend on the cost of living crisis, how easily people can see a GP and the Rwanda policy.'

title: How Burnley, Luton and Sheff Utd can escape the Premier League’s worst-ever relegation race
lead: There is no chance of all three clubs surviving, but with Bournemouth close and some Six Pointers in the offing – there is still (some) hope
author: Michael Hincks

body.text: If calling this the Premier League's worst-ever relegation race seems harsh, first let's look at the numbers.
Since the Premier League era began, no three teams have had fewer points combined after 12 games than the 15 shared by Burnley, Luton Town and Sheffield United.

To cut them some slack, this record-low total was also seen in 2020-21, when it was once more Sheffield United – on one lowly point – plus West Brom and Fulham, but this is no statistic you want to match, for all three of those clubs would eventually go down, more than 10 points adrift of safety.

For the sake of contrasts, the bottom three of Newcastle, Sunderland and West Brom in 2008-09 had a healthier 35 points combined at this stage (only Sunderland would stay up), while for those screaming 'that Derby County season' around about now, even the Rams had six points after 12 games in 2007-08 – picking up just five more in their next 26 – and held a combined 21 with Bolton and Wigan.
How it started
How it finished
How it has started

It is therefore hard to draw on positives. The three promoted clubs who are yet to keep a clean sheet between them are already bringing up the rear, concrete proof that the gulf is growing, that getting to the 'promised land' is one thing and staying there is another matter entirely.

Perhaps we should take this is a sign that it will only get worse. Luton stunned us all, including themselves, with promotion to the Premier League. They would go on to spend a league-low £9.5m on players in the summer, some £500k shy of their reported £10m stadium refurb, and so their season is panning out as many expected.

There were higher hopes for Burnley, supposedly boosted by their parachute payment and Vincent Kompany's nous, but that has simply not translated this season, with the Clarets rock-bottom of the table and in the goals scored column, and are currently on a five-game losing streak to boot.

Sheffield United fans may currently feel the most optimistic off the back of four points in their last two games, but having been here before just three seasons ago, the club still shrouded in takeover mystery know all too well about fading hope.

The saving grace is that Bournemouth sit just three points above Luton in 17th, but with Fulham a further three ahead in 16th it is already looking like, at best, three from four – and therefore a miracle needed for only one of Burnley, Luton and Sheffield United to go down.
It would take some change.

Turf Moor has been more sandcastle than fortress this season, with opponents kicking them down for fun and prompting a stark record; the Clarets becoming the first side in English top-flight history to lose their first six home games of a season.

This feels like an obvious point to start. Nottingham Forest survived on their home form last season, picking up 30 of their 38 points at the City Ground. Somehow Burnley must forget this run, press the reset button during the international break, and look at their next three Turf Moor matches as an opportunity for nine points.

Burnley host West Ham on 25 November and then Sheffield United on 2 December, a double-header soon followed by Everton visiting Turf Moor later in December – a trio of games that will tell us if there is any fight left within this downtrodden team.

Few predicted a start as bad as this, and Kompany's reputation has subsequently taken a massive hit. The man tipped to succeed Pep Guardiola at Manchester City – given Burnley's attacking brand of football in a Championship season where they amassed 101 points – is now managing the only club yet to score double digits in the Premier League.

The step-up has been challenging, to put it mildly, and in their bid to stay up they will probably need to strike gold in January – but finding a striker worth their weight in the stuff during a notoriously difficult transfer window is not so simple.

On paper there is a little more to shout about for Luton, who are creating more chances than their fellow basement clubs, recording 140 shots to Burnley's 122 and Sheffield United's league low of 105.

They also have a better defensive record, resulting in a goal difference of -12 to their rivals' -21, but conversely this is a cause for concern as it has still only produced one win in 12, and still no clean sheet.

Sure, Luton were seconds away from a famous victory over Liverpool, and only narrowly lost to Manchester United on the weekend, but the club dubbed underdogs from the beginning did not need near-misses.

They needed three points rather than one against Liverpool, a result to boast about, to give the squad, the staff and the supporters all a lift. To once more use Forest for reference – as the play-off winners the previous season – their wins over Liverpool and Arsenal proved invaluable in their successful survival mission last year.

Luton could do with at least one shock of their own, and next month they host Arsenal on 5 December then Manchester City on 10 December. Easier said than done, but against the Gunners under the Tuesday night lights of Kenilworth Road? The timing of this fixture has been crafted by the upset gods.

Four points adrift of safety, it is tough knowing even a win isn't good enough to claw your way out of the relegation zone, but Sheffield United certainly know they can drag Bournemouth right back into the scrap on 25 November.
Sheffield United play host, and they arguably have to win, for the detrimental six-point swing should they lose could be terminal – for Luton and Burnley, too.

The recent win over Wolves and draw at Brighton proves Sheffield United can defy the odds, but they simply have to improve going forward and somehow find a way to hold more possession, with only Luton below them for shots on target (33 versus 32) and passes made (4,124 versus 3,609).
It is looking a mammoth task, and the outcome will become even clearer once they have faced Burnley at Turf Moor in December. A Six Pointer if ever there was one.

title: Why Gabriel Jesus has joined Brazil squad despite missing five Arsenal games with injury
lead: The 26-year-old has not featured for Arsenal since the end of October but has travelled to Brazil for their World Cup qualifiers
author: Oliver Young-Myles

body.text: A potential club vs country row is brewing between Arsenal and Brazil with Gabriel Jesus set to report for international duty despite not playing for the Gunners for three weeks due to a hamstring injury.
Jesus is one of three Arsenal players included in Fernando Diniz's squad for the World Cup 2026 qualifiers against Colombia and Argentina with Gabriel Magalhaes and Gabriel Martinelli also included.

But while Gabriel and Martinelli have featured regularly in recent weeks, Jesus hasn't played for Arsenal since putting in a man-of-the-match performance against Sevilla in the Champions League on 24 October. The 26-year-old was not even named on the bench for Saturday's 3-1 win over Burnley.
When asked whether Jesus would link up with Brazil this week, Arteta replied: 'I'm going to talk to the doctors and him [Jesus] because he didn't do any training with us.
'He's far from working with the team, but it's an internal communication between the club and the national team. The first intention is always to seek the best for the player.'
Fifa rules dictate that clubs must release their players to national teams if they are selected.

Annexe 1 of Fifa's regulations on the status and transfer of players dictates: 'Clubs are obliged to release their registered players to the representative teams of the country for which the player is eligible to play on the basis of his nationality if they are called up by the association concerned. Any agreement between a player and a club to the contrary is prohibited.'
The rules add that it is 'mandatory' for players to be released in 'all international windows listed in the international match calendar', which applies to Brazil's upcoming fixtures.

Last month Bukayo Saka travelled to England's St George's Park training base to be assessed by the Three Lions' medical team before being released due to injury, and Brazil are evidently keen to analyse Jesus for themselves too.

That decision appears to be driven by a situation last month where they decided against selecting Martinelli due to injury, only for the winger to come off the bench and score the winner against Manchester City in Arsenal's final game before the international break.

'In the last call-up, we hadn't called up Martinelli, from Arsenal,' Diniz said last week. 'He didn't report to the CBF [Brazilian Football Federation] in a very complete way, so we didn't imagine that Martinelli would be ready to play against Venezuela and Uruguay, and he was ready to play before our games.

'Because of this too, we are going to bring Gabriel [Jesus] to find out the real conditions, because we still have 15 days until the games, so we believe that he can be able to play, because I like him a lot.
'We have 24 players on the list, and if something happens to him we won't need to change the squad.'
Jesus' inclusion is likely to ruffle some feathers at Arsenal considering he has struggled with injury problems ever since joining the club from Manchester City.

The striker missed three months of last season due to a knee injury sustained while representing Brazil in the Qatar World Cup last winter and missed the start of this campaign after undergoing surgery on the same knee.

In total, Jesus has been unavailable for 26 Arsenal games in all competitions since the start of 2022-23, which equates to just under 40 per cent of their total matches. He has played just 364 minutes of Premier League football this term.

Eddie Nketiah has generally deputised for Jesus with the recent England cap starting nine league games, but he has had fitness issues of his own lately. Leandro Trossard led the line against Burnley at the weekend and bravely scored the opening goal of the game.

title: Fulham will pay the price for alienating loyal fans if poor form spirals
lead: Charging £160 for a match ticket in the Premier League could soon backfire if Fulham find themselves back in the Championship
author: Daniel Storey

body.text: There is no panic yet, nor would it be merited, more a lingering fog of disillusionment that could mature into resentment if things continue to get worse.
Fulham have won two league matches since the opening day, at home to Luton Town and Sheffield United. They have lost two home west London derbies, fixtures that they won last season.
Fulham head into the final international break of the year in 16th place. It is their lowest position since promotion.

No panic because nothing is irrevocably broken. Beating teams in the bottom three might be enough to stay up this season. Fulham are on course for 38 points and that almost certainly will be. Marco Silva has signed a new contract after rumours of an engineered exit last summer. Joao Palhinha has done the same, which may at least keep him in Fulham white until summer 2024.

Still, gradual decline doesn't feel much better than collapse when you're living it. Andreas Pereira is not quite at it. Antonee Robinson has scored two unfortunate own goals. Willian is nowhere near his 2022-23 boon. Adama Traore has suffered niggling injuries. The loss of Aleksandar Mitrovic is monstrous, for both his goals and his often cartoonish fighting spirit.
Don't overlook the second aspect: Fulham have taken two points from the eight matches they have trailed this season, roughly half as many per game as in 2022-23.

The goals are the headline. The regret is not that Mitrovic left per se, because he was so publicly insistent that he was going, but that a better succession plan hadn't been arranged given the, shall we say, unpredictable nature of Mitrovic's personality.

The replacement for the 57 goals in 69 games over Mitrovic's last two league seasons was Raul Jimenez, a man without a Premier League goal since March 2022. He did at least break that duck against Aston Villa on Sunday.

'There's also the age issue,' says Jack Collins of the Fulhamish podcast – at 28.6 Fulham have the oldest average starting lineup in the Premier League by almost half a year. 'There was a lot made about ensuring Willian's new contract was signed, but he has struggled to get going at all.

'With the age profile of the squad the most skewed towards older players across the whole division, Fulham feel like they're lacking a bit of youthful spark, and perhaps seeing the slow decline of some of the older members of the squad too.'

Roughly, two distinct things are happening here. The first is that Fulham are inevitably regressing to the mean. Last season, they were the Premier League's data kings, the statistical anomalies. Fulham overperformed their expected goals for total last season by 5.8 (thank you, Mitro) and overperformed their expected goals against total by 12.8 (thank you, Bernd Leno). Now they are underperforming their xG for and… okay, Leno is still making lots of saves.

The other, slightly less tangible, effect is that Fulham are drifting a little. Mitrovic's departure – and its nature – hit the club hard because they felt helpless to stop the rampant force of player and agent power and the state ownership of Saudi Pro League clubs.

The proceeds were reinvested, but new signings are still acclimatising. Calvin Bassey and Alex Iwobi, the two most expensive, have started nine league games between them. Timothy Castagne and Jimenez are 'effort' players, who give their all but don't necessarily make the mind dance.

This is all entirely normal. Teams drop off. Teams suffer when a key player leaves and their manager is the subject of serious interest. Teams with new players take time to gel. Teams who stay up in their first season occasionally find life more tough thereafter.

The current Premier League table sees the current promoted clubs in the bottom three positions and then last year's promoted clubs in the next three places up. Lesson: the Premier League is a difficult beast to wrestle with as a newbie and you are never totally safe.

In those circumstances, a club must look within for solace. It must re-engage and re-energise its supporter base and its community so that when it needs to lean on them for reciprocal love, it finds only open arms. The clubs that punch above their weight are the ones where everyone pulls in the right direction; ignore the fanbase's strength at your peril.

Which is exactly what Fulham have done. Last weekend, the Fulham Supporters Trust and Fulham Lillies organised a protest against what they consider to be extortionate ticket prices at Craven Cottage. And if you don't think that paying £160 for a match ticket or £3,000 for a season ticket represents ludicrous overcharging because of 'supply and demand', then I'm afraid you're more a part of the problem than the solution.

'It's not just the existing fans,' says Collins. 'A large part of the outcry about ticket prices was the fact that the club are risking alienating a whole generation of new local fans, who would have been tempted to come to the Cottage (instead of Chelsea or Brentford) by sensible pricing strategies.
'It's all well and good bringing tourists and day-trippers in, but if Fulham were to end up back in the Championship, that becomes a less viable income stream than someone who lives in Hammersmith.'

This isn't just about fleecing supporters who can just about afford to pay the ticket prices through gritted teeth or freezing out those who can't, although that is a gross treachery of what a football club should stand for.

It is that these misguided strategies actively erode the identity of Fulham's support. The money struggles of the past, the campaigning against the merger with QPR, the loyalty when they had to leave the Cottage; all of this is risked for nothing other than avarice.

There is a misaccusation that Fulham is a club followed exclusively by the wealthy, those viral images of cheese and red wine on away trips. It isn't, or at least not amongst the core support. It's about families, parents and children, the elderly and groups of mates, who support Fulham because they were born into supporting Fulham and are being pushed from centre stage because their club seems to think that it doesn't matter who sits in their seat.

In doing so, Fulham have risked that they will not need to rely upon the faith that only long-term loyalty and experience can guarantee. If this team continues not to score goals, the day-trippers will go elsewhere. If Marco Silva needs a crowd to get behind his team, he might wonder why it seems a little quieter than usual.

There is no panic yet, nor would it be merited. But that fog of disillusionment is aptly placed over Craven Cottage and it won't shift until results improve drastically or Fulham choose to appreciate that their supporters are hurting. Football clubs don't always need supporters as much as we need them, but they always will eventually. This is not the time for everything else to drift too.

title: Sir Bobby Charlton’s funeral was the stately send-off that England’s greatest deserved
lead: As the pall bearers entered Manchester Cathedral, throats tightened at the awful finality of the pageant – England’s greatest, gone
author: Kevin Garside

body.text: MANCHESTER — How many lined the streets it is hard to say. The talk was of 30,000 defying the attentions of Storm Debi to pay their respects to Sir Bobby Charlton.

Manchester was at its monochrome best, a pewter November sky evoking a sense of the post-war city that greeted a 15-year-old tyro in 1953 when Charlton traded Ashington for another gritty, industrial landscape to sign schoolboy forms at Old Trafford.

He could not have imagined then at the start of his footballing odyssey that he would have the career he had, that he would come to define Manchester United and England the way that he did. Nor that it would end like this, a deified figure universally loved, sent to the next world via a quasi-state occasion attended by the future king of England.

The presence of the Prince of Wales symbolised the significance of Sir Bobby's contribution to English cultural life, one prince acknowledging the regal power of another. He was there in his role as Football Association president, but he might easily have found a reason to be elsewhere and sent his apologies instead. His appearance shone a light on the absence of United manager Erik ten Hag, who did just that. An unbreakable prior engagement in the Netherlands, apparently.

Neither was there any representation by the owners. The Glazers believed their turning up would have been a distraction. Not as great a distraction as their not being there, another example of their dislocation, of how little they understand of the club they own and its community.

Enough of the people who really mattered to Charlton, players past and present, honoured him at Manchester Cathedral, including Paddy Crerand, Alex Stepney, Willie Morgan, Martin Buchan, Mark Hughes, Steve Bruce, Peter Schmeichel, Roy Keane, Paul Scholes, Nicky Butt, Michael Carrick and Ole Gunnar Solskjaer. Each understood the importance of the thread linking the last of the playing survivors from Munich to the club they too would represent.

Sir Alex Ferguson was among the first to arrive, as was always his custom at Carrington. The one remaining Charlton brother, Tommy, took his place quietly without fuss. As the clock ticked towards 2pm the chatter in the chamber began to ease, replaced by the sonorous notes of the organ telling us the cortège was near. It all felt terribly stately, an occasion of tremendous weight.

At four minutes past the hour, the pall bearers entered through the South Entrance. Throats tightened at the awful finality of the pageant. The idea that Sir Bobby Charlton, a beacon of such towering permanence, was being borne along the nave in a small oak casket seemed impossible to process. England's greatest gone. There was not a peep, save for the footsteps of the pall bearers.

The order of service was fronted by a photograph of a smiling, avuncular Sir Bobby.  On the back the god-like youth was knelt over a ball in classic pose, his red shirt remarkable for its obvious, repeated use. It was probably laundered that very day by his landlady.

Prince William joined in proudly at the rendition of the first hymn, Abide With Me, a weekend of remembrance slipping into an extra day of sincere contemplation. Former chief executive David Gill was the first to speak in tribute. He seemed nervous, the words spilling too quickly like a prefect addressing a school assembly, frequently tripping over monotone phrases. He went through the Charlton ledger, the 758 United appearances, the 249 goals, the 106 England caps.

It is hard to offer originality when the story is universally known. Besides a career as profoundly nourishing as Charlton's can never be captured by numbers. Towards the end Gill faltered over Munich, the emotion stifling his delivery. We can forgive him that.

John Shiels, CEO of the Manchester United Foundation, reminded us of the magic inherent when a ball was at Sir Bobby's feet, and how he would implore the kids at his eponymous soccer school to smash it into the back of the net, the best expression he knew of the game he loved. Sir Bobby said he wanted the experience of playing football to feel like Christmas Day, the epitome of childhood happiness. It wouldn't have occurred to him how smashing a ball like he did was impossible for mortals. What came to him so easily was a gift that defied instruction.

Keane, clean shaven for the occasion, appeared to hang on every word of Sir Bobby's grandson William Balderston, who spoke of a devoted grandfather who would indulge the passions of all his grandchildren equally, including plane spotting at Manchester airport. Who knows what private torment Charlton had to negotiate to accomplish that after the horrors of Munich.

The tragedy of 1958 provided the narrative force of Charlton's remarkable story. It troubled him that he was not among the eight team-mates and 23 victims in total, who lost their lives. The widow of the last to be pulled from the wreckage of British European Airways flight 609 alive was among the 1,000 mourners.

Stephanie Morgans, who lost her husband Ken more than a decade ago, pierced the solemnity with touching anecdotes from their shared youth learning how to be Manchester United players under Sir Matt Busby.

She recalled how they would visit Jesse Harold's tailors, just across from the cathedral where Charlton now lay, on Deansgate to get new suits. 'If one did it they all had to have one.' It was the time of Frank Sinatra. The suits would be accessorised with trilbies a la Old Blue Eyes. Bobby the crooner.

Who knew? These were days of innocence and possibility. The world was at their feet. Bobby had yet to meet Norma. Hard to imagine Charlton as anything other than a modest family man, but before all the serious stuff that comes with family life, he was just one of the lads, a fun-loving sprite.
'Always a lovely boy,' she said. Indeed, a man of character, charm, humility and kindness, a footballer the like of which we shall never see again.

title: Chelsea are starting to look like Pochettino’s Tottenham – and that’s a good thing
lead: Fast, fun and full of mischief – are Chelsea finally on the up?
author: Sam Cunningham

body.text: After Stamford Bridge had emptied and the dust settled on arguably the Premier League's most entertaining game of the season, there emerged amid the wreckage a glimpse of what Chelsea can become under Mauricio Pochettino.

It has not been the smoothest of starts under the club's Argentinian head coach, yet that result – and the performance that produced it – coming so soon after that bizarre but important victory against high-flying Tottenham Hotspur has offered a gaze into the crystal ball at what could lie ahead.

Chelsea went toe-to-toe with Pep Guardiola's reigning Treble holders – 'for me the best team in the world,' as Pochettino later described them – and earned a deserved point that could easily have been three.

This Chelsea – young, inexperienced, expensively assembled – is still in its infancy but is starting to reflect the Spurs sides that Pochettino repeatedly coached to beat the odds with Premier League title challenges and a Champions League final. Yet where Pochettino overachieved with Spurs, the potential is so much greater at Chelsea to reinstate the west London club as regular trophy winners of the peak Roman Abramovich years for seasons to come.

Pochettino referred to building 'from zero' (outsiders may consider starting with a squad costing more than a billion pounds hardly zero) since he arrived at the start of July. All the signs had been pointing to a project that wasn't working, yet among the inconsistent performances, the defeats to West Ham, Nottingham Forest and Brentford, the 10th place in the Premier League table, there are shoots of the force Chelsea can become. Under Pochettino, they now have eight points against traditional 'Big Six' sides – unbeaten by Liverpool, Arsenal, Tottenham and now City.
How close are they to competing where the club's owners, the fans and Pochettino expect them to be? 'Still far away, like the distance on the table,' Pochettino half-joked after the City game.

The 10 points to Tottenham in fourth does feel like a chasm, but how close can they get to Champions League football this season? There were fingerprints of Pochettino's great teams everywhere in the draw with City: fast, fun, fearless, executing clever moves, playing incisive, direct football, with passion and mischief.

The darting run from Thiago Silva to the near-post corner of Manchester City's six-yard box to nod in Conor Gallagher's corner unmarked to level when you might have expected older iterations of Chelsea under Pochettino to crumble after falling a goal behind.
Enzo Fernandez celebrating a tackle on Phil Foden on half-way in front of his manager like he had won a World Cup final, which he has some experience of.

Cole Palmer slaloming through City's defence, in the way a young Dele Alli used to under Pochettino at Spurs, with fast feet and quick thinking, only denied a goal by Ederson's great save. Palmer is only 21 and already has four goals and two assists in his last five games, received his first England call-up on Monday morning after other players withdrew. He could soon represent exceptional value at the £42.5m Chelsea paid Manchester City.

Being unafraid to wind up opponents. Many players nowadays tone down celebrations against former clubs. Not Raheem Sterling, who celebrated his and Chelsea's four goals as though they were against bitter rivals, not a former employer who had boosted his bank balance by millions of pounds.

Sterling was the centre of everything, energetic, playing with a point to prove. Recently dropped from Gareth Southgate's England squads, it is of mutual benefit to Sterling and Chelsea for him to spearhead the project.

There is Nicolas Jackson, who is around the same age as Harry Kane when the England striker had that first breakout season in Pochettino's first at Tottenham, scoring 32 goals in 56 appearances while still an England Under 21 player. There is the mini-revival of Gallagher, who the owners appeared happy to cash in on in the summer but has been one of Pochettino's leading players.
'We've been trying to build slowly but surely,' Sterling said. 'There's been some setbacks. We're making those steps.'
They took great strides in the space of eight days, the question is how far can it carry them?

title: Have Arsenal stumbled upon a solution to their No 9 problem?
lead: Gabriel Jesus’ injury troubles have led to a lot of experimentation
author: Daniel Storey

body.text: This is an extract of The Score. Click the sign-up box below to receive the newsletter every Monday morning this season for Daniel Storey's verdict on all 20 Premier League clubs

I think we have to conclude that Gabriel Jesus cannot be relied upon to start more than 25 league games a season. The striker is wanted by the Brazilian football federation this week, who it seems aren't convinced by Arsenal's prognosis, but Mikel Arteta has said that the latest injury is a huge worry and Jesus is not expected to play until December. He has played 363 minutes in the Premier league this season.

As alternatives, Arteta has started Eddie Nketiah as the central striker and seen him score a hat-trick. He has started Kai Havertz there in the Community Shield and seen him do about as much as he has in central midfield. He started Leandro Trossard as a false nine and as a more conventional centre forward.

Nketiah probably wouldn't agree, but you wonder whether Trossard might just be the answer moving forward. His creativity, tendency to drift left (and allow Gabriel Martinelli to move centrally) and set-piece delivery are all useful to Arsenal. Trossard, naturally a left winger, is able to drag defenders out of position that could be crucial against a deep-lying defence. Against Burnley, he was able to repeatedly find space around the penalty area and scored when finding space inside it.

Interestingly, Arteta spoke last season after a win at Leicester about how the switching of positions with Martinelli can increase Arsenal's creativity: 'He [Trossard] is so good in the small spaces. He's got that creativity to open people up and I'm really happy with him. We have the option to play Leo as the No 9 and we have the option to play Gabi as the No 9 and Leo on the left.'

The theory is this: if Nketiah plays and is presented with chances, that system works fine. But if Nketiah is starved of the ball, Arsenal can become a little formulaic and opponents can double up on Martinelli and Bukayo Saka, particularly if Havertz isn't a threat from midfield. In those scenarios, they would be better having the flexible forward.

title: Erik ten Hag is being dragged into the Man Utd vortex – and that only ends one way
lead: Ten Hag has exhausted every plausible bounce back theory. The chasm between his pledges and outcomes has become so great as to rob his words of weight and meaning
author: Kevin Garside

body.text: Welcome to Erik ten Hag's parallel universe, a Manchester United world full of certainty and optimism, where the best of all possible outcomes is a function of doing things the right way. His way.

Thus did his pre-match conference ahead of the trip to Fulham have about it a familiar ring. Talk of standards and the need to match them every day, the requirement to win every match, of the players putting in every effort and being ready for the game. This way lies Camelot.

This was true after every defeat this season, each promise to do better begetting a new failure. There have been eight losses so far. Ten Hag has exhausted every plausible bounce back theory. The chasm between his pledges and outcomes has become so great as to rob his words of weight and meaning.

The negative momentum that has built on the back of losses against Tottenham Hotspur , Arsenal, Brighton, Crystal Palace and Manchester City in the Premier League, Bayern Munich and Galatasaray in the Champions League and Newcastle United in the Carabao Cup appears increasingly unstoppable.

Ten Hag has crossed a disturbance threshold. Every day invites more speculation, making it all but impossible for him to function. Boardroom inertia resulting from the turbulent ownership dynamic has added to the sense of crippling stasis. United are stuck, unable to judge whether sacking or keeping Ten Hag is the way to go. Meanwhile, results continue to collapse, taking morale with them.

The gutless disintegration against City was the high-profile emasculation that destroyed almost all of the goodwill that remained from his first season at Old Trafford. The defeat to Newcastle poured petrol on a crisis that seems more likely to deepen at Fulham than lift.

Last season's qualification for the Champions League and victory in the Carabao Cup, no matter how routine that ought to be for a club of United's size and wealth, were seen as evidence of a plan working and reinforced the idea of Ten Hag as a turbo coach, a zen-like figure reconnecting United to the club's mythical past.

How different his uncompromising qualities appear now. The strict application of rules that led to the exit of Cristiano Ronaldo and relegation of Marcus Rashford to the bench over timekeeping breaches was judged to be one reason why the team was improving. Now the principled approach that, among other things, keeps Jadon Sancho in exile, is seen as unhelpful and inflexible. With Rashford misfiring and Antony almost beyond use, Ten Hag's negative attitude towards an asset that cost United £73m has lost its force.

The club denies replacements for Ten Hag are under consideration. Of course they do. To admit otherwise would be to escalate the pile-on. There are reports of anomie behind the scenes, of a club barely able to function as a result of the delays surrounding Sir Jim Ratcliffe's proposed buy-in.

That we have been here before is seen by a few loyalists as a reason to keep Ten Hag in his post since changing the manager has achieved little in the 10 years since United last won the Premier League under Sir Alex Ferguson. However, that ignores how the experience of managing United warps and perverts to such a degree it robs coaches of their capacity to function effectively. As a result they end up becoming a part of the problem. This appears to be the juncture Ten Hag has reached.

He cannot admit this, of course, and so deeper into the vortex he is dragged, his words of defiance, his justifications and excuses, spilling out behind him: 'They [the players] are positive. They want to put this right, and we know the standards here. We have to match them every day.

'We've had two big setbacks, but we'll fight back. The dressing room is strong, the staff are strong and this manager is strong. I'm convinced in the long-term, they will be hard to beat, and they know how to do it.'

This will be put to the test again at Craven Cottage, the site of their last victory in London. Though three points adrift of United in the table, Fulham have lost one match fewer. Their problem, like the visitors, is scoring goals, only nine to United's 11.

It might be United find something at the bottom of the barrel that breaks the sequence. They did manage a hike in urgency in the second half against Newcastle before Joe Willock drove the blade home a third time. Matching the opposition, sprint for sprint, tackle for tackle is the minimum requirement. If Ten Hag wants this to be about standards, he might start with that.

title: Anthony Martial has done nothing for nine years – he sums up everything wrong with Man Utd
lead: Nobody can quite believe Martial remains a United player, but despite spending over a billion pounds, there is nobody else to turn to
author: Pete Hall

body.text: Apathy. In November. That is where Manchester United fans are at.

There are no surprise defeats anymore. Resignation is etched over supporters' faces as they walk into the stadium. No team is too small to get a result at Old Trafford these days, not when the hosts are beaten before they enter the pitch.

One moment summed up the psychological state of United fans on Wednesday night. As he sauntered off, having barely got out of walking pace for eight years, the reaction to Anthony Martial being substituted, with a fifth home defeat in 10 already this season, a worst run since 1930, already in the bag, the scene was as remarkable as you could witness in any sporting arena.

It is not uncommon, especially in the Theatre of Nightmares this season, for fans to boo a player being subbed, applaud the withdrawal of an underperforming star or cheer the introduction of a young upstart who can finally put one of a multitude of leading actors floundering on stage out of their misery.

What made Wednesday such an incongruous sight was there was a mixture of all three simultaneously, bound together with fits of laughter. All that was missed was some flying rotten vegetables to add to the hilarity. Nobody can quite believe Martial remains a United player, having done virtually nothing for nine seasons in Manchester.

Supporters have the world's once most expensive teenager to provide a perfect summation of just where their team are at – a wonderfully gifted, overpriced footballer who simply isn't interested and is happy to underperform, knowing full well his well-serviced career in English football can continue in an environment where mediocrity is rewarded with a five-year contract.

Martial was never going to cause Newcastle any problems on Wednesday night, no matter what iteration of the talented Frenchman turned up and regardless of how many full-backs Eddie Howe shoehorned into his side, given his need to rotate the pack. Martial checked out a long time ago.

We have all been taken for fools at some point. There was the season under Ole Gunnar Solskjaer where Martial became the first United striker since Romelu Lukaku to hit 20 goals in a season, having been deployed in a central role after initially playing out wide.
'He is becoming more and more like a top No 9 each week,' former United midfielder Paul Scholes said at the time.
'Sometimes he is unstoppable,' Solskjaer gushed. How did Martial repay a manager who remains the only coach to get the best out of him? By crying 'treachery' for overplaying him in a later interview.
Coaches who get to see what he can do behind closed doors on the training pitch, when things are much less intense, have all fallen into the trap.
'We play our best football when Anthony Martial is in the team,' Ten Hag eulogised last season. The ability is unquestionable, the application not so much.
It is not just his laissez-faire approach to matters on the pitch that makes Martial the perfect yardstick to examine what's left of this once great club.
United have tried to sell Martial, loaned him out to mid-table Spanish teams, but he keeps coming back like a bad penny.

Like supporters, his teammates must raise a wry smile every time he does. A player with 11 league goals in the last three and a half seasons keeps getting given a chance, because the recruitment at Old Trafford has been so bad that over a billion pounds later, there is nobody else to turn to.
Nobody wanted Martial to be there on Wednesday night. Not even the player himself. But this is Manchester United now – even their own supporters are laughing at their demise.

title: Robelinda2: Fans in mourning as ‘Aladdin’s Cave’ of retro cricket footage vanishes from the internet
lead: The disappearance of an Australian archive of cricket footage has been compared to ‘burning the Great Library of Alexandria’
author: Richard Edwards

body.text: Forget Angelo Matthews being timed out, the real cricket controversy taxing fans across the globe isn't on the field of play, but in the murky landscape of video copyright on the internet.
On Sunday, Rob Moody – a Melbournian known to cricket lovers throughout the world – tweeted that his Robelinda2 YouTube channel, a cricket insitution, was no more.

Moody had recorded footage from pretty much every professional game played in Australia since 1982-83, and the world relied on his eclectic collection to get their cricket fix during the 2020 lockdown. His hundreds of videos generated millions of views as grounds around the world stood empty.
He had been threatened with a number copyright strikes by an account going under the name @MarhabaCricketIndia, which claimed the 'legitimate and exclusive digital rights'.

'We are open to constructive dialogue and hope for a swift resolution that respects the rights and interests of all parties involved,' read a section of the statement subsequently released by the account.

Moody has never made a penny out of his Aladdin's Cave of footage, but says he would like to come to an agreement, if only so he can download the now missing videos in one accessible place rather than a series of hard-to-locate hard drives in his house.

The cricket world responded to events faster than Sri Lanka's helmet chin strap technician. Aussie cricket commentator and journalist, Geoff Lemon, tweeted that this vanishing archive of cricket footage – much of it from the 1980s – was like 'burning the Great Library of Alexandria.'

i inadvertently wakes Moody up with a phone call – with countless media commitments for outlets in Australia the previous day, he needed a decent night's sleep. So, did Tuesday feel like the first day of the rest of his life?
'There's so much stuff going on, it's just crazy,' he says. 'I haven't done anything on the channel for the whole of this year, then all of a sudden, out of nowhere, it disappears.

'I have no idea who Maharba Cricket are. With something like this, there's always the danger of your account being terminated but it's just so much, and not just the stuff I have made public there are videos on there that I haven't (made public) too.
'There are also heaps of personal videos. I've probably got them all on hard drives somewhere, but finding them might take a while.'

He's not wrong. Previously on VHS videos, the footage was transferred into 25 folders stored at his house, with each folder containing 1000 CDs. That gives you an idea of the scale of what effectively amounts to a lifetime of chronicling the sport he loves. A past-time that the cricket world has John Wayne to thank for.
'Back in the ‘80s, you have the home movie revolution and that's exactly what it was – a revolution,' he says.
'All us Aussie kids could remember our dads watching the same John Wayne movie over and over again and then the cricket highlights came on after.

'In my case, I never got to see how the match ended. The tape ended halfway through the game, so I ended up recording every other match in that 1982-83 one-day series so I wouldn't have to put up with watching half of Australia vs England in the World Series at the Gabba. It was the Botham pig match, when they sent a pig out onto outfield with his name on it.'

Moody then set about recording every cricket match screened Down Under, while also teaching himself the editing skills he recognised in those who put together the 21-minute highlight packages for Australia's international matches on Channel 9. He had no idea of the appetite that would develop for his work around the globe a generation on.

'Everyone wants to see that stuff – no-one is saying ‘hey, check out our archive from 2012, no-one cares,' he says. 'It's a massive nostalgia trip. I've tested it by putting up something dumb in the ‘80s and something good in 2012. I put a video of Viv Richards leaving a ball and it went crazy.
'I've got some others to release as well. I've got all the fours hit by Glenn McGrath in Test cricket – they're all shit. I've also got every cut shot ever hit by David Boon in chronological order.'
Some may be niche in the extreme, but Moody's highlight reels have stood the test of time. Until now.

title: ‘I can help Jadon Sancho’ – Ex-winger Joe Cole wants to talk to Man Utd exile after Erik ten Hag rift
lead: The England winger has not lived up to his £73m price tag and has been frozen out by his manager at United
author: James Gray

body.text: Jadon Sancho was reportedly removed from the Manchester United WhatsApp group, but there is at least one person in football who wants him to pick up the phone this week.

It is understood Sancho, 23, has been exiled from first-team training, forced to use separate changing rooms and even has to eat with the United academy rather than the main canteen after falling out with manager Erik ten Hag.
But former England winger Joe Cole says he would welcome a conversation with Sancho, who has not played for United since August, in an effort to get his career back on track.
'I would love to speak to him and his people and try to help,' says Cole, who will be part of TNT Sports's Champions League coverage when United take on Copenhagen on Wednesday.
'He's clearly a young player with a heck of a lot of talent.
'It's not going to work for him at Manchester United and I don't know what his next move is, but there's still a player in him.
'If I was a young coach I would take Jadon Sancho and fancy I could get the best out of him.
'Give me Sancho as a manager every day of the week… …a player of that quality needs a little bit of nurturing and help. I'd take him, and I think he's a good player.'
Sancho was once one of Europe's hottest properties, with United eventually winning the race to sign him from Borussia Dortmund for £73m in 2021.
However, the club's struggles since have coincided with a stagnation in his career and he has scored only 12 goals in 82 appearances.

He was once seen as a trailblazer in English football after rejecting a contract at Manchester City to move to Germany, and his success there influenced fellow Englishman Jude Bellingham's decision to head to Dortmund.

Bellingham's blossoming also earned him a big money move, Real Madrid paying £90m for him this summer, but unlike Sancho, he has gone from strength to strength. The 20-year-old has scored 13 goals in 14 games for Los Blancos, including two in his first Clasico appearance to beat Barcelona 2-1.
He did have offers to return to England, including links with United, but he instead chose to continue his development away from his home country.
'Jude would still be doing the business [if he had gone to Old Trafford],' Cole adds.
'And Man Utd would be a lot better with Bellingham. Would he be doing as well as he's doing at Real Madrid? No.
'He's got everything, ticks every box and does everything right.
'[While} Jadon is a fantastic footballer, particularly with the talent and quality he's got, he needs a little bit of nurturing and he might need a bit more maturity.'

A club in crisis and a manager with whom the relationship has broken down is not the place for a young player to be, and increasingly players could start to look at a United contract as a millstone round their neck rather than an opportunity to join one of the world's biggest clubs.

But for those already at the club, Ten Hag's allies in the dressing room seem to be dwindling. Cole saw five managers sacked during his seven years at Chelsea as a player and knows how a manager's precarious position can start to infect a squad.
'We can only look at what we see on the pitch and the body language of certain players – and that's subjective a little bit as well – but the results ain't good enough, so we know that,' says Cole.
'I look at it and I've talked to other players who are looking at it and they just don't look like they're a team that are together.
'There will be players there sitting there thinking, ‘If he [Ten Hag] goes, this might be good for me'. That's the truth.

'He is a situation where he needs the lads to produce a performance for him. If I was Erik Ten Hag and had a situation where my job was on the line, I would want to know, ‘Who is with me and who is against me?'.
'I'd identify the characters, not necessarily the quality of players, who are with me. Like Scott McTominay. He would be in my team.
'Is he better player than Bruno Fernandes or even Casemiro? Possibly not. But you have got to get a result, but I would go with the players who are with me and the staff.
'You have to pick up on things. It might be a glance, it might be the body language, or their air in training.

'If he loses the next three or four games and gets sacked, he is just a footnote in the history of Manchester United. If he wants to be a success, he needs to identify the players he can trust – and they might not be the best players. But he needs to identify the players who are going to sweat blood and tears to get a result.'
